Description

A fireplace combines both lighting and sound effects. Since light and sound control are on separate control layers, I found myself wanting a fast way to light or extinguish fires.

I was using Monk's Active Tiles to handle this, but it is a lot of clicks to setup a single instance.

The result is that I automated the ability to link an active tile to an overlapped light and sound. When you double-click the active tile, the fire will either light or extinguish and a message will be written to the chat log.

Steps to create:

  1. Place a light source with desired settings.

  2. Place a sound in the same location.

  3. Place a ground tile that covers your light and sound effect and just save it with default settings.

  4. While that ground tile is selected in the UI, click the Create Fireplace macro.

You will end up with an active tile that is visible only to the GM and is activated with a double-click.

Considerations

If you duplicate a scene with fireplaces or export/import to a different world, the fireplaces may not function. You can fix them by running the Rewire Fireplaces macro.

This module was born from a collection of macros that I wrote to make running games more efficient. It wasn't written with the intention of publishing, but I have decided that maybe it could be of use to othersâ€¦

If you have questions you can either log an issue on github or message caiusmartius on Discord.

Description

I found myself placing a bunch of lights in a scene and then later wanting to change the look. Since there was no mass-edit for lights, this became an exceedingly tedious process.

Created a macro that lists lights in the scene by their unique attributes. You can select a light group and then alter their most common attributes.

Instructions

  1. Run the Change Lights macro.

  2. Select the light group you want to modify.

  3. Edit the fields you want to alter.

  4. Click Update.

Description

These are helper methods created to give or take money to your players. A chat message will be created to indicate what has transpired.

Give

This allows you to give money to your players. Click Manage Money and then click Give.

Notes

  • If no player tokens are selected, the money will be evenly distributed to all players in your configured players folder. (As long as they are in the scene).

  • You can select 1 or more tokens to explicitly define who should receive money.

  • This function is always going to split the amount between chosen token actors.

Take

This allows you to take money from your players. Click Manage Money and then click Take.

Example

Say you are at an inn and your 4 players decide to buy a room for the night. You can say a room is 4gp per night and if they agree, you would c

  • Click Manage Money

  • Click Take

  • Enter 16gp

  • Click Take.

The result is that 4gp would be taken from each player.

Notes

  • If no player tokens are selected, the money will be evenly collected from all players in your configured players folder. (As long as they are in the scene).

  • You can select 1 or more tokens to explicitly define who should be giving money.

  • If not everyone can afford the amount you have selected, nothing will happen and you will receive a private message in chat indicating which players do not have enough money.

  • This function is always going to split the amount taken between chosen token actors.

Equalize

This will simply take all money from the players and redistribute it evenly.

Notes

  • If no player tokens are selected, the money will be evenly distributed across all players in your configured players folder. (As long as they are in the scene).

  • You can select 1 or more tokens to explicitly define who should be evenly distributing money.

Description

This works in conjunction with Zhell's Backpack Manager. When you open an item of type backpack, the SDND icon will be displayed. When clicked, the icon will create a managed backpack if none exists or it will render a dialog allowing the backpack to be transferred to another character.

Create Backpack

  • A backpack actor of type NPC will be created under a folder called Managed Backpacks.

  • The backpack will inherit the permissions of the owner.

Transfer Backpack

  • You will be asked to select from a list of player characters in the scene.

  • The backpack will be transferred to the chosen player.

  • The permissions of the backpack will now be in sync with the new owner.

Backpack Synchronization

When you edit the ownership permissions of an actor, SDND will automatically sync the changes to the player's backpacks.

(This is useful in the case where you want to assign temporary ownership to an additional player for the purposes of botting.)
